title: Why can't we honor enemies in the new honor system?
body: Sometimes the nicest, friendliest, or chillest people can be the enemy. I'd be sad if I couldn't honor someone who deserved it on the enemy team. For example if they had a rough lane but stuck through, got flamed but dealt with it in a positive way, or made the game more fun in general.

replies.body: They expressed that honouring opponents was something they were looking to expand into after the initial release, but for release they want to keep things as simple as possible.

Lately, I've been running into really chill enemy players. It's a nice experience. Like, at the end of every game, we strike up conversations and I sometimes end up adding them. It's awesome to see this side of the community.

It's fun being the nice enemy every now and then. A little while ago I got a game as top Renekton vs a Riven. The Riven openly announced they were rusty. 

I did end up killing Riven twice in the early game, and to be blunt I could have done it more, but I decided against it. Every now and then I would get ganked by multiple people with Riven and end up having to fight them all off, but instead of just slaughtering Riven every time she went to lane to farm, I told her in all chat to farm, that I wouldn't touch her. I would walk past her and farm the minions behind her, she would farm the same.

It was a normal game, of course, and that could be considered throwing. But to be honest, I have no care for winning alone. Stomping someone while they're down is no fun. I'd rather lose when I deserved it instead of winning early just because I knew the laning phase better (that, and I was Renekton, a rather powerful early game champ).

I got 3 honorable opponents after that game. It was more enjoyable than just stomping the enemies because of an early lead, and I wouldn't have minded losing because they weren't terrible sports about it.

That's fair. I do it in-game because I like it, though ofc. not to the point of dying or taking free harass for it. Regardless, it's not mandatory.

What's sportsmanlike in League? Lots of stuff! Being a graceful winner and loser, complimenting your opponents on plays well-done, and just... idk, interacting with them in a nice way relative to the game? It's hard for me to define concretely off the top of my head, but it's the same as sportsmanship anywhere else. Play to win, and talk to make them less salty about it. When you do lose, accept it gracefully. Compliment people - friend and foe - on things they did well! Accentuate the positive, esp. to people who might be tilted anyways.

Mind, I do a lot of it naturally, since I have a somewhat sunny personality (well, most of the time), so I often underestimate the struggle for people who are more competitive. I realize that it's not just something as easy for everyone. That's not a snarky thing or bragging or anything - people are just naturally different. I'm happy, I have strong game knowledge, but I'm honestly pretty terrible at actually playing League. People with better instincts and faster reaction times completely wipe the floor with me. Each person has their own strengths and weaknesses. A lot of success is learning to play to your strengths, shore up your weaknesses, and avoid things you're not so good at... unless they're fun and you don't mind being not so good at them. :P

But yeah, just be nice, go out of your way to say positive things, and rephrase and reframe negative in a constructive light. That doesn't mean negativity is inherently bad - sometimes it's _good_ - but always treat it with great care. Doing so does wonders for your own team morale (which is a _huge_ and badly underestimated resource) and for everyone's general satisfaction with the game.

Yeah if they do so, you should have 3 ways of honoring then.

Well played: These players outdone you (and your team even) and deserve praise for their skills in the game.

Disciplinarian: Defending the enemy team form toxicity from their own team. Should be awarded to enemy player for who refuse to tolerate trolls and toxic players  abusing your team.

I like the other two, though.

To expand on MysticMan answer: they want to make Honour counts in order to push people to behave better because they want to get Honour. So  they want to promote people giving Honour, almost force people to participate in the Honour system, and the easiest way to do that was to strongly encourage people to give Honour every game. And how do you make people give Honour? You force them to go through a neat and clean interface where they can easily do it. But neat and clean means you have to present as few options as possible, and that meant removing opponents (or the possibility to honor multiple people), the reasoning being that you interact with your team much more, so you have more reasons to honor them on average.

(From my experience, you also have more reasons to report them too, but that's another story.)
